text: infection in the first wave was significantly lower than second wave so i doubt it covered all the weakest individuals. if it is true, the spread of infection follows the small-world network where there are small super-spreaders which can infect a lot of people in its immediate neighborhood. small-world network will just need two to three hops to reach these vulnerable ones like in social networks.

text:
We know that infections in the second wave are concentrated among younger people, I think that's some combination of

1. A lot of exposed older people died in the first wave
2. Because of (1), congregant homes and older people in general are being far more cautious
3. Independently, young people are not taking things very seriously

Independently, young people are not taking things very seriously

text:
> Or the people who were most vulnerable already died the first time around
I know too many people who are very vulnerable due to age and/or comorbidities, myself included, who have survived by aggressively social distancing since March. I think that there is a large pool of people who are vulnerable, who may get hit very hard if a more contagious form of the virus comes in the next wave.

text: The only hope I see (until all of the vulnerable people are able to be vaccinated) is the improvements on therapeutic treatments, <@U013QVATCKT> of M10 has done some great stuff getting funding for testing of already approved drugs for treatment shortly after infection, before it’s too late.
